prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection/Characterization of Envelopes in Serpens
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Use the 1.3mm continuum to detect the dust emission from material in a circumstellar disk and/or inner envelope associated with a VeLLO. The emission can be used to estimate the mass of material in the disk or inner envelope. This material represents the reservoir of material that is likely to be accreted over the next 10,000 years and indicates the likely nature of the VeLLO.
Use the CO J=2-1 line to detect the outflow. The outflow confirms that the candidate is indeed a low luminosity source associated with the Serpens cloud. A background AGN is expected to have a much broader CO line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe simultaneously the 1.3mm continuum and CO J=2-1 line in order to achieve our science goals. The 1.3mm band was chosen as an optimal trade-off between the rising emission from the dust with increasing frequency and the decreasing primary beam size with increasing frequency. The CO line is the most common outflow tracer, and the continuum is the best tracer of overall mass in the circumstellar region. The sensitivity requirements for the project were determined based on the results of previous observations and the desire to optimize between sensitivity and sample size.
Our science objectives require detecting emission from inner envelopes and outflows, which likely have low surface brightness, on spatial scales up to 10"; therefore, the relatively large (1") synthesized beam is best for our program. While the disk is expected to be unresolved in our observations, resolution of the disk and detailed separation of the envelope and disk are not necessary to accomplish our science goals. We realize that large scale emission from the envelope will be resolved out; we have compensated for that in arriving at our mass sensitivity estimates, and will model it for the actual data. This is primarily a detection and broad characterization experiment.
The time request for the survey is set by the continuum sensitivity requirement of 0.1 mJy/beam at the distance of Ophiuchus (125 pc; de Geus et al. 1989) or 0.07 mJy/beam at the distance of Serpens (415 pc; Dzib et al. 2010). Using existing MIPS 24 and/or 70 micron detections of VeLLOs in Ophiuchus, we used the radiative transfer models in the DIRT on-line tool (Wolfire & Cassinelli 1986; Pound et al. 2004) to predict the 1.3mm fluxes for a range of embedded luminosities (restricting to L<0.1 Lsun), density profiles, and extinctions. For sources at the distance of Ophiuchus, the typical flux at 1.3mm was greater than ~1 mJy, even for envelope masses of ~0.001 Msun. For Serpens, the greater distance is roughly compensated for by the longer integration time and the larger physical extent of the inner envelope probed by ALMA. Our existing CARMA detections provide a consistent picture with the model results, with 1.3mm fluxes of a few to few 10s of mJy for sources at the mid to high end of the VeLLO luminosity range.
For the CO J=2-1 line observation, we have chosen a velocity resolution of 0.3 km/sec which is sufficient for the outflow detection and resolving the core line width. To test this point, we have taken example dataset from our previous observations of VeLLO outflows, created images with the proposed velocity resolution, simulating the impact of limited uv coverage. ALMA was able to detect the past examples of low velocity outflows. The expected CO line sensitivity, ~15 mJy/beam/channel, is sufficient based on the past detection levels from IRAM, SMA, and CARMA.
Because we require spatial scales up to only 10" to characterize the inner envelope and because we are not mapping potential outflows, simply detecting them if present, we do not require ACA observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Detection/Characterization of Envelopes in Ophiuchus
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Use the 1.3mm continuum to detect the dust emission from material in a circumstellar disk and/or inner envelope associated with a VeLLO. The emission can be used to estimate the mass of material in the disk or inner envelope. This material represents the reservoir of material that is likely to be accreted over the next 10,000 years and indicates the likely nature of the VeLLO.
Use the CO J=2-1 line to detect the outflow. The outflow confirms that the candidate is indeed a low luminosity source associated with the Ophiuchus cloud. A background AGN is expected to have a much broader CO line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe simultaneously the 1.3mm continuum and CO J=2-1 line in order to achieve our science goals. The 1.3mm band was chosen as an optimal trade-off between the rising emission from the dust with increasing frequency and the decreasing primary beam size with increasing frequency. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Very Low Luminosity Objects (VeLLOs) are young stellar sources that are defined by luminosities less than 0.1 solar luminosity and rising mid-infrared spectral energy distributions. But what exactly are they: brown dwarfs or low-mass stars in formation, systems exhibiting low accretion, extremely young objects? We propose to characterize the VeLLO class through observations of 1.3mm continuum and CO J=2-1 outflow emission of a sample of 12 high-probability candidates in the Serpens and Ophiuchus molecular clouds. This survey is expected to double the number of confirmed VeLLOs, provide estimates on the masses of their inner envelopes, and help address questions concerning the nature of VeLLOs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Cycle 0, PI: Lee Mundy, Proposal 2011.0.00712.S Cycle 1, PI: Marc Pound, Proposal 2012.1.00488.S
